drug.name: Roxatidine acetate
drug.description: Roxatidine acetate is a specific and competitive H2 receptor antagonist. It is currently approved in South Africa under the tradename Roxit.

article.citation: Murdoch D, McTavish D: Roxatidine acetate. A review of its pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic properties, and its therapeutic potential in peptic ulcer disease and related disorders. Drugs. 1991 Aug;42(2):240-60.

drug.indication: For the treatment of disorders of the upper gastro-intestinal region that are due to an excess of hydrochloric acid in the gastric juice, i.e. duodenal ulcers, benign gastric ulcers. Also for prophylaxis of recurrent gastric and duodenal ulcers
drug.pharmacodynamics: Roxatidine acetate suppresses the effect of histamine on the parietal cells of the stomach (H2-receptor antagonist). This suppressive action is dose-dependent. As a result, the production and secretion, particularly of gastric acid, are reduced. Roxatidine acetate has no antiandrogenic effects and does not influence drug-metabolizing enzymes in the liver.
drug.mechanism-of-action: The H2 antagonists are competitive inhibitors of histamine at the parietal cell H2 receptor. They suppress the normal secretion of acid by parietal cells and the meal-stimulated secretion of acid. They accomplish this by two mechanisms: histamine released by ECL cells in the stomach is blocked from binding on parietal cell H2 receptors which stimulate acid secretion, and other substances that promote acid secretion (such as gastrin and acetylcholine) have a reduced effect on parietal cells when the H2 receptors are blocked.
drug.metabolism: Roxatidine acetate is rapidly metabolised to the primary, active desacetyl metabolite.

classification.description: This compound belongs to the class of organic compounds known as n-benzylpiperidines. These are heterocyclic Compounds containing a piperidine ring conjugated to a benzyl group through one nitrogen ring atom.

category.category: Drugs for Peptic Ulcer and Gastro-Oesophageal Reflux Disease (Gord)

atc-code.level: DRUGS FOR PEPTIC ULCER AND GASTRO-OESOPHAGEAL REFLUX DISEASE (GORD)

drug-interaction.name: Cefditoren
drug-interaction.description: The serum concentration of Cefditoren can be decreased when it is combined with Roxatidine acetate.

drug-interaction.description: Roxatidine acetate can cause a decrease in the absorption of Dabigatran etexilate resulting in a reduced serum concentration and potentially a decrease in efficacy.

article.citation: Agrawal SS, Alvin Jose M: Roxatidine, an H(2) receptor blocker, is an estrogenic compound--experimental evidence. Syst Biol Reprod Med. 2010 Aug;56(4):286-91. doi: 10.3109/19396368.2010.496894.

polypeptide.name: Histamine H2 receptor
polypeptide.specific-function: The H2 subclass of histamine receptors mediates gastric acid secretion. Also appears to regulate gastrointestinal motility and intestinal secretion. Possible role in regulating cell growth and differentiation. The activity of this receptor is mediated by G proteins which activate adenylyl cyclase and, through a separate G protein-dependent mechanism, the phosphoinositide/protein kinase (PKC) signaling pathway (By similarity).

go-classifier.description: adenylate cyclase-activating dopamine receptor signaling pathway
G-protein coupled receptor signaling pathway, coupled to cyclic nucleotide second messenger
phospholipase C-activating dopamine receptor signaling pathway
positive regulation of adenylate cyclase activity involved in G-protein coupled receptor signaling pathway
